bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 164, Number 57 (Tuesday, April 10, 2018)][Pages H3095-H3096]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. GOODLATTE:H.R. 5447.[[Page H3096]]Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 8, Clause 8

By Senator Grassley from Committee on the Judiciary filed written report. Report No. 115-339.
Committee on the Judiciary. Hearings held.

item.latestTitle: Orrin G. Hatch-Bob Goodlatte Music Modernization Act

item.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 415 - 0 (Roll no. 154). (text: CR H3522-3536)
Passed/agreed to in House: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 415 - 0 (Roll no. 154).(text: CR H3522-3536)
Considered as unfinished business. (consideration: CR H3560-3561)

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 5447.
Considered under suspension of the rules. (consideration: CR H3522-3542)
Mr. Goodlatte moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended.
Placed on the Union Calendar, Calendar No. 499.
Reported by the Committee on Judiciary. H. Rept. 115-651.
Reported by the Committee on Judiciary. H. Rept. 115-651.
Ordered to be Reported by the Yeas and Nays: 32 - 0.
Committee Consideration and Mark-up Session Held.
Referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary.

Music Modernization Act

This bill makes various changes to copyright law related to sound recordings, including providing protection for sound recordings fixed before February 15, 1972, creating a system for paying royalties to producers and sound engineers, and establishing a statutory blanket license for digital music services. The blanket license allows music services to distribute sound recordings covered by the license without negotiating for the rights for each individual recording, as long as the music service complies with the license's requirements, such as paying the required royalties.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
